description:
This includes a number of fix-ups for things that raise errors or cause issues in the docs build.

I'd appreciate it if @jzuhone signs off on the changes I've made to the flash frontend and his analysis modules.
title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw: LGTM.
content.html: LGTM.

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.html:
Shoot, I meant to include this on a separate pull request but it looks like I've accidentally included a fix for the hse_field.py cookbook recipe for this PR. Rather than declining a bunch of PRs I'm just going to leave this be since they're at least tangentially related.

Matthew Turk this includes a possibly dubious fix for smoothed covering grids. Would love it if you could take a look at 9acc670.

This also implements the flat property for YTArray, which I've shamelessly adapted from astropy.

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw:
I was going to handle the free free quantity by making it work as a field
and summing it. It actually is possible to add your own derived quantities,
but that's not how I think that should be implemented.
content.html: I was going to handle the free free quantity by making it work as a field and summing it. It actually is possible to add your own derived quantities, but that's not how I think that should be implemented.

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw: How do custom derived quantities work now?  `add_quantity` no longer exists, which led me to think it hasn't been implemented yet
content.html: How do custom derived quantities work now? add_quantity no longer exists, which led me to think it hasn't been implemented yet

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw:
Auto-registering subclasses. But that has not yet been documented, and I
don't think we need them for free free.
content.html: Auto-registering subclasses. But that has not yet been documented, and I don't think we need them for free free.

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw: OK.  What about the change I made to smoothed_covering_grid? Is that the same issue you were having with periodic ghost zones for non-periodic data?  If so I doubt that it's the correct way to fix the error I was seeing.
content.html: OK. What about the change I made to smoothed_covering_grid? Is that the same issue you were having with periodic ghost zones for non-periodic data? If so I doubt that it's the correct way to fix the error I was seeing.

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw: It's not just owls (btw, I've disabled it for the time being), units tests fail too. See http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-3.0_unittests/740/ for details. Basically some objects that used to be `YTArray` or `YTQuantity` are now `YTArrayIterator` and comparison fails
content.html: It's not just owls (btw, I've disabled it for the time being), units tests fail too. See http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-3.0_unittests/740/ for details. Basically some objects that used to be YTArray or YTQuantity are now YTArrayIterator and comparison fails

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw: I do not think this should be changed.  We use smoothed covering grids for ghost zones, and for all periodic datasets, this will not cause the failure you were seeing.
content.html: I do not think this should be changed. We use smoothed covering grids for ghost zones, and for all periodic datasets, this will not cause the failure you were seeing.

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw: This ended up coming down to differences between numpy 1.7 and 1.8.  I removed `YTArrayIterator` after finding that using it in numpy 1.7 introduces some performance penalties for operations like `nanmax`, which use `flat` internally.
content.html: This ended up coming down to differences between numpy 1.7 and 1.8. I removed YTArrayIterator after finding that using it in numpy 1.7 introduces some performance penalties for operations like nanmax, which use flat internally.

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw: I see no reasons to hold this up.  @jzuhone if you get a chance to look at the changes made to your code, I think it's fine to hit the button.
content.html: I see no reasons to hold this up. John ZuHone if you get a chance to look at the changes made to your code, I think it's fine to hit the button.

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw: I would have thought these should stay as warnings, but it's not a big deal either way.
content.html: I would have thought these should stay as warnings, but it's not a big deal either way.

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw:
My justification is that by default in a notebook this will be printed with a scary red background color.  This is particularly bad when iterating over a time series, since it gets printed once for each dataset. 

Every single FLASH dataset I've seen emits this warning for `checkpointfilenumber`, so I think it would be best if we reduced the direness of these warnings.  On `info` log level, recent versions of the notebook won't print anything unless you explicitly turn on logging.
content.html:
My justification is that by default in a notebook this will be printed with a scary red background color. This is particularly bad when iterating over a time series, since it gets printed once for each dataset.

Every single FLASH dataset I've seen emits this warning for checkpointfilenumber, so I think it would be best if we reduced the direness of these warnings. On info log level, recent versions of the notebook won't print anything unless you explicitly turn on logging.

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw: Wait, recent versions of the notebook won't print anything on `info` level?  That seems like a problem to me.  We put a lot of *useful* info into `info` level, and anything that *isn't* useful should be downgraded to `debug`.  I am strongly against doing things someone might not want without notifying the person at the helm that we're doing them, and this concerns me.
content.html: Wait, recent versions of the notebook won't print anything on info level? That seems like a problem to me. We put a lot of useful info into info level, and anything that isn't useful should be downgraded to debug. I am strongly against doing things someone might not want without notifying the person at the helm that we're doing them, and this concerns me.

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw: Yeah, it's news to me that info messages don't get shown in the same way.
content.html: Yeah, it's news to me that info messages don't get shown in the same way.

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw:
For this specific issue, I don't think it's a big deal.  Like I said, the warning is emitted by every single FLASH dataset I've ever loaded.

It might be the case that I'm fooling myself based on my experiences with IPython 2.x, but I think it *does* suppress logging at the info level unless you explicitly turn it on with something like the following in your notebook:


```
#!python

import logging
logger = logging.getLogger()
logger.setLevel(logging.info)
```

FWIW, I don't think it's particularly useful to see `info` debugging information in the notebook, since it robs you of valuable vertical screen real estate.  I realize we've had this discussion in the past - if we want to see this logging information in all notebooks by default we'll need to add something like that to `yt.__init__`.  See e.g. this notebook: http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/ngoldbaum/d48b2ae50b565fe06094
content.html:
For this specific issue, I don't think it's a big deal. Like I said, the warning is emitted by every single FLASH dataset I've ever loaded.

It might be the case that I'm fooling myself based on my experiences with IPython 2.x, but I think it does suppress logging at the info level unless you explicitly turn it on with something like the following in your notebook:

import logging
logger = logging.getLogger()
logger.setLevel(logging.info)

FWIW, I don't think it's particularly useful to see info debugging information in the notebook, since it robs you of valuable vertical screen real estate. I realize we've had this discussion in the past - if we want to see this logging information in all notebooks by default we'll need to add something like that to yt.__init__. See e.g. this notebook: http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/ngoldbaum/d48b2ae50b565fe06094

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw:
So, I had a look at it again. I'm OK with the notices about the parameter overwrites being set to `info` instead of `warning`. 

I'm on the fence about `gamma`. Thing is, there are many perfectly legitimate reasons for `gamma` not being in a dataset (dark matter only sims, or multispecies runs where gamma is a spatially dependent variable). So I guess it probably can be `info` as well.
content.html:
So, I had a look at it again. I'm OK with the notices about the parameter overwrites being set to info instead of warning.

I'm on the fence about gamma. Thing is, there are many perfectly legitimate reasons for gamma not being in a dataset (dark matter only sims, or multispecies runs where gamma is a spatially dependent variable). So I guess it probably can be info as well.

pullrequest.title: Fixing a number of docs build issues.

content.raw: Yeah, my justification for changing the `gamma` warning was similar to the reasoning I shared above - it was printing dozens of scary-looking warning messages for the `ParticleTrajectories` notebook - one for each output file.
content.html: Yeah, my justification for changing the gamma warning was similar to the reasoning I shared above - it was printing dozens of scary-looking warning messages for the ParticleTrajectories notebook - one for each output file.
